title: 103_s1178
content: The Act may be cited as the "Great Lakes Federal Effectiveness Act" and establishes the Great Lakes Research Council. The Great Lakes Research Council is established to advise and coordinate federal research activities for ecosystem protection of the Great Lakes. Within one year, the Council will provide an assessment of necessary research activities. The Great Lakes Research Council will prepare a document within one year, assessing research activities and Federal expertise needed to fulfill the Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement goals. The Great Lakes Research Council will assess Federal research programs and personnel related to the Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement goals, providing recommendations for research priorities and participating in relevant meetings and conferences. The Great Lakes Research Council will assess Federal research programs, identify topics for meetings and conferences, make recommendations for data collection, advise on a data base for the Great Lakes ecosystem, and ensure dissemination of results and information. The Great Lakes Research Council will advise on data collection, establish a comprehensive data base for the Great Lakes ecosystem, and ensure timely dissemination of research findings. The Council will be comprised of a research manager with extensive knowledge and scientific expertise. The Great Lakes Research Council will consist of research managers from various agencies with expertise in the Great Lakes ecosystem. The Great Lakes Research Council will include members from various federal agencies, such as the United States Coast Guard and the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, as well as other relevant federal departments. Non-Federal employees may also serve as ex officio members. The Chairperson will be elected by the members for a two-year term, with a limit of two consecutive terms. Members are entitled to compensation while performing official duties. The Great Lakes Research Council members serve for two-year terms with a limit of two consecutive terms. Members receive compensation for official duties. Federal agencies must cooperate with the Council to implement recommendations. Federal agencies that are members of the Council must cooperate to implement recommendations, provide necessary personnel, services, or facilities, and furnish data upon request to achieve the purposes of the Act. The Council will invite the International Joint Commission to serve as the principal coordinating body and may reimburse costs for activities. The Act will not affect the authority of Federal agencies to conduct Great Lakes research. Sec. 105 of the Act defines key terms related to Great Lakes research, including the definition of the Council as the Great Lakes Research Council and the scope of the Great Lakes region. Great Lakes research involves applying scientific and engineering expertise to study physical, chemical, biological, and socioeconomic processes in the Great Lakes ecosystem. The Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement is a bilateral agreement between the United States and Canada signed in 1978 and amended in 1987.
